School and side projects

Below are some of the projects I've worked on both as part of my Masters Degree, and as side projects. For more, you can check out my Github page.

Projects

Bikeshare

Poster

For this project, I used data made available by Capital Bikeshare. The purpose was to analyze how the system has grown, and what the main stressors to the system are. We used the data available through Capital Bikeshare, but then also had to merge in station location data, as well as scraped and merged weather data for each day of the system's history.

First, we looked at which bike stations are most popular for beginning and ending a trip. We saw that generally the start and end stations are close together, and there is a network of stations that are visited most. This helps to know which stations are likely to be busiest, and where new stations would get the most use.

We also looked at ridership levels throughout the day on a weekday and weekend. There are two types of riders in the system: registered (who pay a subscription fee) and casual (no subscription). During the week, registered users spike a great deal around rush hour commute times, the casual riders slowly grow throughout the day. The weekend rides are basically the same for casual and registered riders. This means that the system needs to be prepared for heavy usage around work schedules during the week.

Weather also has a large effect on ridership. More riders rent bikes as the temperature warms up, to a point. Beyond about 75 degrees, the ridership goes down because it is too hot or uncomfortable to ride.

We also saw that from the most frequently rented from stations, some of the stations have more bikes being rented than returned, while others have more bikes being returned than rented. Capital Bikeshare could learn about how to better distribute and move bikes during the day based on this information so there is always a bike or space available for someone who needs it.

Data Warehousing

Final Paper
Poster

This group project focused on taking randomized data maintained by the School of Information Studies at Syracuse University and eventually creating a data warehouse that focused on enrollment practices at the school.

The group determined a business purpose for the project (to more efficiently allocate course sections) and then went to work building on the data warehouse lifecycle. We identified attributes that we would include in the data warehouse, as well as where each piece of data was coming from, then we created snowflake diagrams to show how our data would be joined together, then we staged the data, performed an ETL flow from the source database to the target database. We did this using SQL as well as Microsoft SSIS.

Once the data was in the data warehouse, we were able to create a MOLAP cube and then bring it into Microsoft Excel and used PowerPivot tools to create business intelligence dashboards that showed which courses were under-enrolled, which had long waitlists, and which professors were the most popular.
